summary: The Union of India has moved the Supreme Court challenging the final judgment and order passed by the High Court at Calcutta in WPCT No.78/2021 setting aside the order dated 22.10.2021 passed by the Central Administrative Tribunal, Principal Bench (New Delhi) in exercise of power under Section 25 of the Administrative Tribunals Act, 1985. This is an appeal against an order of the High Court at Calcutta passed under Section 25 of the Administrative Tribunals Act, 1985. The issue before us is whether a person who has filed an Original Application under section 19 of the Tribunal Act to redress any grievance and the cause of action for challenging an order of transfer of such an application from the Bench where it was filed and pending, to another Bench in the invocation of or disinclination to invoke, the power under Section 25 of the Act.

summary: The National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (NCDRC) has set aside an order passed by the State Consumer Disputes Redressal, Commission, Haryana at Panchkula which allowed an insurance company to repudiate its policy on the ground that it could not claim in toto, made by the owner of the vehicle, in case of loss of the vehicle due to theft, merely on the ground that there was a delay in the company regarding the theft of vehicle? summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up the appeal of Shambhu Kharwar against the order of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad dismissing his plea for quashing of a criminal case registered against him for allegedly having an affair with a woman. The Supreme Court has quashed an FIR registered under Section 482 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) against a man for allegedly forcing a woman to marry another man. The Supreme Court of India (SCCI) has held that rape is not a crime under the Indian Penal Code (IPC) if the offence of rape is established in terms of Section 375 of the IPC which sets out the ingredients of the offence.

summary: Two appeals have been filed in the Supreme Court of India challenging the decision of the Union of India to reduce the benefit of 100% exemption from excise duty granted to it by the Government of India to ten years from the date of commencement of commercial production. Before the advent of the new GST regime, both of the appellant’s units were enjoying a full refund of the central excise duties paid by them as provided for in the exemption notification dated 25th June, 2003, pursuant to the Office Memorandum dated 17th February, 2003. The Goods and Services Tax (GST) Council in its meeting on 17 October, 2022 resolved that in the event any existing exemption/incentive, etc., was to be withdrawn, then it would be withdrawn by way of a reimbursement mechanism through the budgetary route.

The Division Bench of the Karnataka High Court has dismissed a writ appeal filed by an appellant against a Permanent Lok Adalat’s order setting aside an award of Rs 2,40,583. summary: Two appeals were heard by the Kerala High Court in the year 2022 on the issue of legality of the appointment of a lecturer by the University of Kerala. The University Grants Commission of India ( UGCR) issued the University Grants Commission of India ( UGCR) Regulations, 2009 (hereinafter, “2009 UGCR) on 11.07.2009 (hereinafter, “2009 UGCR / first amendment) which prescribed the minimum eligibility condition for recruitment and appointment of Lecturers in Universities/Colleges/Institutions and provided the following: “NET/SLET shall remain the minimum eligibility condition for recruitment and appointment of Lecturers in Universities/Colleges/Institutions. The University of Kerala appointed Dr. Jayakumar as Lecturer on the basis of the results of the 2009/10 UGCR.

summary: The present appeal is directed against the judgment dated 307 passed by the High Court of Judicature at Madras, Madurai Bench whereby the appeal preferred by National Insurance Co. Ltd., against the award passed by the Motor Vehicle Tribunal, Tiruchirappalli, was allowed. The Insurance Tribunal ruled that the Insurance Company was liable to pay compensation to the dependants of the late Ambassador K. Ramya on the basis of the loss of income caused to them by the accident and interest at the rate of 7.5% per annum. The appellants have been granted reasonable flexibility in determining ‘just’ compensation and are not bound by any rigid arithmetic rules or strict evidentiary standards to compute loss unlike in the case of damages.

summary: The Income Tax Appellate Tribunal (ITAT) has quashed an assessment order of the Principal Commissioner of Income Tax (CCIT) against a company for alleged tax evasion of more than £2m. The Income Tax Appellate Tribunal (ITAT) has held that an assessment order passed by the Principal Commissioner of Income Tax (hereafter the AO) was not sustainable in law because the assessee company did not exist on the date of the assessment order, as it had amalgamated with another assessee company. The assessee company (MRPL) was represented by Mahagun Relators Private Ltd.

summary: The appellants in this appeal are Lalankumar Singh and others. The High Court of Bombay has dismissed a Criminal Writ Petition against a summons issued to the Directors of a Mumbai-based pharmaceutical company for manufacturing and distributing a drug which was found to be unsafe. Shri Singh submits that as per the provisions of the Drugs and Cosmetics Rules, 1986, it is the duty of the Quality Control Laboratory to carry out tests of the strength, quality and purity of the substances as may be required to be carried out by him under the provisions of Part X of the said Rules.

summary: The Supreme Court has granted leave to Pawan Kumar to challenge his discharge from the Railway Protection Force (RPF). The order of discharge came to be passed on 24th April, 2015. 1 It is true that a person who has suppressed the material information has no right to be appointed or continuity in service, but at least has a right not to be dealt with arbitrarily and power has to be judiciously exercised by the competent authority in a reasonable manner with objectivity having due regard to the facts of the case on hand.

summary: The High Court of Punjab and Haryana has granted leave to the appellant to take maternity leave for the period from 27 June 2019 to 23 December 2019 in terms of Rule 43 of the Central Civil Services (Leave) Rules 1972. summary: The High Court of Karnataka has set aside the common judgment and order passed by the Division Bench of the High Court of Karnataka at Bangalore and upheld the order for recovery of damages in the proceedings initiated under Section 14B of the Act 1952. The appellants have challenged the validity of Section 14B of the Employees' Provident Fund Organisation (EPF) Act 1952, which empowers the Central Government to recover damages from employers who make default in the payment of EPF contributions. The appellant(s) were under an obligation pay and for the contravention of the provisions of the Act 1952, the appellant(s) indeed committed a breach of civil obligations/liabilities.

summary: The High Court of India has issued a notice to the Union of India and the Medical Consulting Committee on a writ petition challenging the decision of the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) to conduct a Stray Round of Counselling for the posts of Assistant Professors (AIQ). The petitioners have approached this Court by way of writ petitions/special leave petitions praying for Special Stray Round of counselling with respect to the remaining 1456 seats remained vacant and to allow them to participate for the vacant seats, which are available after the conduct of the Stray vacancy round of AIQ. The petitioners have moved the Supreme Court seeking directions to the Union of India and the Medical Counselling Committee to conduct a special Stray Round of counselling for NEET-PG-2021 and NEET-PG-2022, to fill up the vacant seats.

summary: Appeal from Madras High Court against quashing of criminal proceedings under Section 141 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881. summary: Krishnamurthy, Gopala and Thimmappa appeal against conviction and sentence of life imprisonment imposed by the High Court of Karnataka, Kalaburagi Bench, for the murder of Venkatarama on 16 February, 2022 In this case, we are dealing with the role and acts of Gopala and Thimmappa and whether they can be individually convicted for murder of Venkatarama. As per the versions given by Dullaiah (PW-6), Dodda Narasimha (PW-7), Channamma (PW-1) and Ramanjaneya (PW-4), Thimmappa was not responsible for the injuries suffered by Venkatarama after he had fallen down.

summary: In a landmark case, the Supreme Court of India has held that an advocate, not being a subordinate officer to the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate (CMM) or District Magistrate (DM), can be appointed to take possession of secured assets and documents relating thereto and forward the same to the secured creditor. The Supreme Court has held that the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate (CMM) or the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate (DM) appointed an advocate purportedly in exercise of powers under Section 14(1A) of the Maharashtra Control of Organised Crime Act, 2002. In this case, the Bank sought to take possession of a secured property by way of sale notice under Section 14 of the Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interests Act, 2002.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up the appeal of Checkmate Services P Ltd vs Commissioner of Income Tax-I on 12 October, 2022. The relevant statutory provisions of the IT Act, with amendments, made by time to time, are as extracted below: By Section 9 of the Finance Act, 1989, the following second proviso was added: "Provided further that no deduction shall, in respect of any sum referred to in clause (b), be allowed unless such sum has actually been paid in cash or by a cheque or draft or any other mode on or before the due date as defined in the Explanation below clause (va) where such payment is realised within fifteen days of the due date."

summary: The Supreme Court of India has allowed an insurance company's appeal against the Bombay High Court's order allowing it to amend the plaint of a civil suit to seek damages. The appellant (original defendant) prayed that the impugned order passed by the High Court should be set aside and the original amendment application filed by the plaintiffs be rejected; and that there being merit in his appeal, the same may be allowed and the impugned order passed by the High Court may be set aside and the original amendment application filed by the plaintiffs be rejected. The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a plea of limitation in a civil case should not be allowed when a party has prayed for an amendment to the pleadings.

summary: The High Court of Karnataka has allowed an appeal by a property developer against a trial court's order directing him to return an amount paid by the plaintiff under a lease-cum-sale agreement. The plaintiff, the Bangalore Development Authority (BDA), sought specific performance of the lease-cum-sale agreement entered into between the first defendant and the BDA, and relief from alienation of the site or the plaint schedule property for a period of ten years. As far as finding of the High Court that the second defendant was not a purchaser for value, it could not be justified, having regard to the evidence which established that the second defendant was the owner of 10 acres of land. As far as finding of the High Court that the second defendant, a 20-years old, at the time of the sale, did not have the wherewithal to purchase the property, it could not be justified, having regard to the evidence which established that the second defendant was the owner of 10 acres of land.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up a case on the issue of tax deducted at source (TDS) and Leave Travel Concession (LTC). The appellant has failed to deduct tax at source from the salary of his employee. Section 10(5) of the Income Tax Act, 1961 reads as follows: “No tax shall be payable on the value of travel concession or assistance received by or due to the individual from his employer or former employer for himself or his family, in connection with his proceeding, or any place in India after retirement from service or after the termination of his service, or any other place in India after the 1st day of October, 1997, between such places, the amount eligible for exemption shall be :— (A) where a recognised public transport system exists, an amount not exceeding the 1st class or deluxe class fare, as the case may be, on such transport by the shortest route to the place of destination; and (B) where no recognised public transport system exists, an amount equivalent to the air-conditioned first class rail fare, for the distance of the journey by the shortest route, as if the journey had been performed by rail.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that juveniles convicted of murder should not be kept in adult prisons. The Supreme Court has directed the District Judges of Uttar Pradesh to appoint efficient lawyers for providing legal aid to the prisoners, who are unable to engage private lawyers, who have been mentioned in the list furnished by the State Government and described to be below 18 years in age on the date of commission of offence. The Allahabad High Court has directed the Juvenile Justice Boards to visit and interview prisoners languishing in jails who claimed to be juveniles in conflict with the law.

summary: The Supreme Court of India, in a landmark case, has said that education is a tool for the betterment of our civil institutions, the protection of our civil liberties, and the path to an informed and questioning citizenry. The Supreme Court of India has held that an educational society, running an educational institution solely for educational purposes and not for the purpose of profit, must be regarded as “other educational institution” under section 10(23Cvi) of the Income Tax Act. The Supreme Court of India has held that a society running an educational institution in the State of Andhra Pradesh was not required to be registered under the Income Tax Act, 1961.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up an appeal against a National Company Law Appellate Tribunal's (NCLAT) order allowing a company to file for bankruptcy. The Supreme Court of India has held that the application under Section 9 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (I&B) can be barred by limitation as provided in Article 137 of the Limitation Act. In a landmark judgement, the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) has ruled that an application for initiation of CIRP can be filed within three years of the date on which an application under Section 7 or Section 9 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC) could have first been made before the NCLT even though the right to sue may have accrued decades ago.

summary: The Delhi High Court has taken up an appeal against an order passed by the National Consumer Dispute Redressal Commission which directed a company to deposit a sum of 265.01 Crores along with interest @ 10% p.a. The appellant has filed an appeal in the Supreme Court against the order of the High Court which held that the appellant has to deposit 50,000/- in terms of second proviso to Section 23 of the 1986 Act while exercising its right of appeal under the 1986 Act. The Attorney General has argued that the right to file an appeal under the 1986 Act has accrued in favour of the appellant in terms of Section 6(c) of the General Clauses Act and that no different intention is discernable from the repealing Act.

summary: The Kerala High Court has ruled in favour of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Thamarasseri in a partition case. The appellant’s sister had made alienations against the appellant’s property in 1981 and 1982 and subsequently sold it in favour of the respondent. The High Court has held and in our view rightly so, that if the respondent had exercised reasonable care as required by the proviso to Section 41, they could have easily found out that there was no power of sale.

summary: The Madras High Court has ruled that the Tamil Nadu Special Reservation of seats in Educational Institutions including Private Educational Institutions and appointments or posts in the State within the Reservation for the Most Backward Classes and Denotified Communities Act, 2021 was unconstitutional. summary: The Rajasthan High Court has directed the appellants to pay the mesne profit of Rs.2,50,000/ per month to the Plaintiffs for the period from the date of filing of the appeal until disposal of the appeal. summary: The Supreme Court of India has held that a cheque that is dishonoured does not represent an enforceable debt at the time of encashment. summary: The High Court of India has held that the Depositories Act, 1996 has the legal effect of overwriting the provisions relating to the contracts of pledge under the Indian Contract Act, 1996 and the common law as applicable in India. summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up a landmark civil case in which a husband and wife have been at loggerheads for more than 50 years over the ownership of a piece of land. In the first round of litigation Ram Devi instituted a suit before the Additional District Judge, Karnal for declaration and injunction challenging the sale deeds executed by Ram Devi. The appellant contended that the doctrine of res judicata would not apply in view of the earlier adjudication as the matter of Ram Devi having a limited estate has been upheld right till the Supreme Court.

summary: The Kerala High Court has set aside the decree for partition passed by the Trial Court in a civil suit filed by two brothers against their father's widow. On 13 June, 2022, the High Court of Kerala, in Kattukandi Edathil Krishnan vs Kattukandi Edathil Valsan, held that the marriage between Damodaran and Chiruthakutty was not valid and that the plaintiffs would not be entitled to a share in the coparcenary property. The defendants have contended that Exhibit A3 does not prove the marriage/long cohabitation between Damodaran and Chiruthakutty.

summary: The Supreme Court has held that an appeal against conviction filed by an accused under Sub-Section (2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 can be dismissed on the ground that the accused is absconding. This is an appeal against the decision of the High Court of Bihar to dismiss an appeal against conviction for non-prosecution. The Supreme Court has ruled that an appeal against conviction should not be heard if the appellant and his lawyer are absent.
